properties.name: GDevelop Linked Chain demo
properties.description: A demonstration using the Physics 2 revolute joint to create a linked chain effect.
properties.author: Jeroen

objects.name: ClickInstructions
objects.string: Click the yellow blocks to make them disappear.

objects.name: DragInstructions
objects.string: Drag this pink box around and amongst the chains.

objects.name: LinkTypeSwitchText
objects.string: Click this text to switch to rope.

events.name: Make the chains. This version has the chains already on screen.

events.comment:
This makes the boxes in the scene a dymanic physics object if it's not marked as being static (i.e. so it is influenced by gravity and forces from any other physics object).
Otherwise it's kept as a static physics object - though this changes while it gets dragged around, as you'll see in the next section titled "Extra bits for the demo".

The Box object has the draggable behaviour attached, so it can be moved around by click and drag.

There can be up to 4 different components to the chain :
  - AnchorStart, the static green block to which a chain link can be attached
  - ChainLink1, the oval shaped chain link. For this demo, this is the only chain link that can be attached to the AnchorEnd block.
  - ChainLink2, the flat looking chain link. For this demo, this is the only chain link that can be attached to the AnchorStart block.
  - AnchorEnd, the static orange/yellow block to which a round (ChainLink1) link can be attached

A chain segment is made up of 2 links, ChainLink1 and ChainLink2. Two different objects are needed to create a revolute joint between them. You cannot create a joint between 2 objects of the same type.

Each chain had 2 identifiers:
  - All links and segments in a chain have the same chainId
  - 2 links (i.e one of each ChainLink1 and ChainLink2) share the same chainSegment value. This is only one way of many to achieve the linking of chainLinks.

The AnchorStart has a chainId that is used to connect all it's chain objects.
AnchorStart is a static physics object, meaning it is does not move and is unaffected by other physics objects and forces.
The very first chain link needs to be attached to the AnchorStart. Otherwise the chain has a good chance of falling off the bottom of the screen when gravity takes effect.
StillProcessing is initially set to false so if there are not enough links then the while block is exited.
This action puts a revolute joint between ChainLink2 and the previous ChainLink1.

This action puts a revolute joint between ChainLink2 and the next ChainLink1. If the next ChainLink1 doesn't exits, then StillProcessing remains false, which will end the while loop that contains these events.
Once all the chain links have been joined, attach the last round chain link to an AnchorEnd block if it exists. Otherwise it becomes free swinging.
These events just deal with the mouse click - dragging of the pink box and removing the AnchorEnd block.
Remove the anchor block if it has been clicked.
MouseJointId of 0 indicates there's no current mouse joint.
Set the box up to be dragged around with the mouse. Turn it from a static object into a dynamic one, so that hte mouse joint works and it can be dragged around.
Update the dragged pink box's position to that of the mouse pointer by changing the mouse joint's target position.
Mouse is released. Make the draggable, non-dropping box to static if it's been marked as such, so it wont't drop down the screen or be affected by the chains.

The LinkTypeSwitchText is a text box instructing the player to click on it to swap between chain and rope images.

The mod command returns the remainder when link1 animation number +1 is divided by 2. This will cyle from 0 to 1 and back to 0.
Changing the animation number also changes the current animation name. Use the animation name to determine what text to put into the link type switching text object.

parameters: "Click this text to switch to rope"
"Click this text to switch to chains"

events.comment: Escape key resets the scene by reloading it
